html:
Etymology[edit]

From vigil (“awake, alert”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈwi.ɡi.loː/, [ˈwɪ.ɡɪ.ɫ̪oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈvi.d͡ʒi.lo/, [ˈviː.d͡ʒi.lɔ]

Verb[edit]

vigilō (present infinitive vigilāre, perfect active vigilāvī, supine vigilātum); first conjugation

  1. (transitive) I watch through, spend in watching, do or make while watching.
  2. (intransitive) I watch, remain awake, keep or am awake at night.
  3. I rise, wake up
  4. (intransitive, figuratively) I am watchful or vigilant.

Derived terms[edit]

  • advigilō
  • ēvigilō
  • invigilō
  • pervigilō
  • vigilāns
  • vigilanter
  • vigilantia
  • vigilātē
  • vigilātiō
  • vigilāx

Related terms[edit]

  • vigil
  • vigilia
  • vigiliārium

Descendants[edit]

  • Aromanian: aveglju, veglju, avigljari
  • → Basque: begiratu
  • Bourguignon: voillai
  • Catalan: vetllar; → vigilar
  • Dalmatian: vejur
  • → English: vigilate
  • Old French: veillier
    • Middle French: veiller, veigler
      • French: veiller
    • Walloon: woeyî
  • → French: vigiler
  • Friulian: veglâ
  • Italian: vegghiare; → vigilare
  • Old Occitan: velhar
    • Occitan: velhar
    • → Italian: vegliare
  • Piedmontese: vijé (inherited?); → vigilé
  • Portuguese: velar
  • → Portuguese: vigiar (semi-learned)
  • → Portuguese: vigilar
  • Romansch: vegliar
  • Romanian: veghea, veghere
  • Sardinian: billai, abbillai, bizare
  • Sicilian: vigghiari
  • Spanish: velar; → vigilar
  • Venetian: vejar, vegiar

References[edit]

  • vigilo in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • vigilo in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • vigilo in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
